The origins of the song’s title have been debated for years. Many believe it was Ringo who came up with the phrase in regard to the state of their touring schedule.

During an interview segment on the Howard Stern Show, Paul McCartney explained that it was actually said by a chauffeur who drove him around after he lost his license for speeding:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UfYVWvdQux4

The phrase was also used for the title of the 2016 Ron Howard documentary, The Beatles: Eight Days a Week – The Touring Years.

Hold me, love me
 Hold me, love me
 I ain’t got nothing but love, babe

In the Queen’s English, “ain’t got nothing but” is a horrifically ungrammatical construction.  And that’s the point.  In this case, the construction calls to mind the 1930s jazz standard “I Ain’t Got Nothin' But the Blues”, by Duke Ellington and Don George.
The early Beatles were revolutionary in the way that they combined Black American jazz & blues with English pops to produce a vigorous new form of rock & roll.  If the early Beatles sound conventional to 21st-century ears, that’s just because they won their musical revolution so completely.

During this chorus only, the word “babe” is replaced with “girl”– reflecting  the usage in the preceding verse.

The song begins with an unexpected fade-in, an early example of The Beatles and George Martin’s willingness to experiment with new sound and production techniques. It was the only second time this technique appeared on a major pop recording (“Come See About Me”, by The Supremes was the first, released one month earlier).
